content.description:
Crux is before and just past the high first bolt that requires a few 5.10+ face moves. The rest of the route is sustained; most hand features are small, side-pull crimps and feet are mostly smears on small, slopey bulges on low angle face.

Move past 3 bolts, then be careful when doing final tricky moves (with your feet 3-4 feet above last bolt). Last 10+ feet after that are runout, but on easy and low angle, 5.7 terrain.
content.location: On Sugar Bun formation (on the mossy side) - To the right of Dirty Dog, route runs next to the arete of the formation.

content.description: Excruciatingly painful thin edging testpiece with a difficult sequence of moves to unlock nearly the whole way makes this one a not often repeated goal reserved only for the truly determined.
content.location: The first independently bolted line left of Fingerlocks.

content.description:
A dime sized edgeing slab.

Start on Make that Move Now Baby and instead of going over the roof after the third bolt, traverse out right around it. Clip the bolt (use double runner) and keep traversing right on a small ledge to a good stance and another bolt. The route continues strait up form here. Just after the last bolt is the crux. Throw for the arete up as high as possible then climb up it to the anchors. This route was put in on lead with all bolts drilled by hand.

A direct start has been worked for this route but still remains elusive to all who have tried. All but about 3ft has been climbed at a grade approaching 5.13 slab. It is an open project... Good Luck!
content.location: Starts on make that move and goes right.

climbs.name: Make That Move Right Now Baby

content.description: Step off a rock on to thin face with bolts, pull past a roof and follow an arete to the top.
Start up Fly Trap and traverse out right following the thin fingercrack.
content.location: Located on the left hand (Northeast) side of the Sugarbun.

content.description: This is the wide but short offwidth/lieback route on the Northeast side of the Sugarbun. Even though this route has been lead with gear it's probably a better option if leading to do without as the crack is too wide and protection too sparse to protect with any degree of safety. The crux is short, leading to easier climbing up the arÃªte above.

On the west side of Sugarbun, climb the splitter finger crack with the oak growing next to it. Climb stemming the tree until you can gain purchase on the crack for the 5.10b variation or climb the crack directly staying off the tree for the direct way that feels more like 5.11.

A tried and true first 5.10 lead for many.

Farley's

ugly, left-facing cousin, East Corner will more fully test your liebacking skills or it can more easily be climbed as a fist crack if you have your skills honed. If not, this is a great introduction to a skill (fists) you will definitely need if you wish to progress to any degree in Traditional climbing. Keep it together for the near vertical crux before gaining a moderate trough and then a bolt before running it out a bit on easy terrain to chain anchors. There is some loose rock in the trough past the crux, so proceed cautiously. Judicious slinging on the second half of the climb should diminish rope drag.
content.location: This semi-classic pain in the ass is - as the name would suggest - located on the East side of the Sugar Bun. A leaning oak tree is growing right in front of the left-facing crack.

content.description: A short and thin face route past three bolts and finally merging with a crack (Mad Dog) and following it to the top.
content.location: Short bolted line to the right of Fly Trap and Mad Dog.

content.description:
I did this a few times in the 70s when it only had two 1/4" bolts and was mossy as hell. Scared the shit outta me then.

It has been nicely cleaned up and with 3 big bolts is real nice now.  Maybe led out for some folks but a lot of fun smearing and good places to hang out and suss out the moves before going for it.
content.location: North side of Sugarbun: left of Wintergreen directly below the tree on the top.

content.description: A natural flowing thin face and lieback route following a faint crack that begs to be climbed. Thin delicate face climbing quickly changes up as you reach the thin crack and becomes a series of thin but very powerful lieback moves through the crux.
content.protection: Bolts. Optional gear .5"-.75" useful to protect easy slab topout.
content.location: Dead center on the North side of the Sugarbun.
